articles.headline: Robert G. Edwards Dies at 87; Changed Rules of Conception With First ‘Test Tube Baby’
articles.snippet: Dr. Edwards, a physiologist working out of the University of Cambridge in England, changed the prospects for infertile couples and forged a brand-new industry.
articles.abstract: Dr. Edwards, a physiologist working out of the University of Cambridge in England, changed the prospects for infertile couples and forged a brand-new industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert G. Edwards, who opened a new era in medicine when he joined a colleague in developing in vitro fertilization, enabling millions of infertile couples to bring children into the world and women to have babies even in menopause, died on Wednesday at his home near Cambridge, England. Dr. Edwards, who was awarded the Nobel Prize for his breakthrough, was 87.

articles.headline: Seeking Relief, Banks Shift Risk to Murkier Corners
articles.snippet: As regulators press for banks to be safer, financial firms are transferring the risk of some assets to a less regulated area of Wall Street.
articles.abstract: As regulators press for banks to be safer, financial firms are transferring the risk of some assets to a less regulated area of Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Banks have been shedding risky assets to show regulators that they are not as vulnerable as they were during the financial crisis. In some cases, however, the assets don’t actually move — the bank just shifts the risk to another institution.

articles.headline: ‘Swatting’ Hoax Tests the Police and Stars Alike
articles.snippet: Pranksters have been filing false reports of breaking horrific crimes at celebrities’ homes in Southern California, designed to provoke the dispatch of SWAT teams.
articles.abstract: Pranksters have been filing false reports of breaking horrific crimes at celebrities’ homes in Southern California, designed to provoke the dispatch of SWAT teams.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — The 911 call came in late Monday afternoon. Two men with guns, one wearing a bulletproof vest, were storming the home of the actor Russell Brand, tucked away on a crest in the Hollywood Hills.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Ian Lovett

articles.headline: White House Budget Curbs Some Deductions for the Wealthy
articles.snippet: Under President Obama’s budget proposal, deductions for tax breaks like mortgage interest and contributions to charities would be capped at a maximum rate of 28 percent.
articles.abstract: Under President Obama’s budget proposal, deductions for tax breaks like mortgage interest and contributions to charities would be capped at a maximum rate of 28 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama is no longer pressing to raise income tax rates on the rich. But that doesn’t mean he thinks the wealthy are paying enough in taxes.

articles.headline: Food Politics Creates Rift in Panel on Labeling
articles.snippet: A committee of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics dismissed a member whose objectivity on genetically modified food was questioned, but she also questioned others’ objectivity.
articles.abstract: A committee of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics dismissed a member whose objectivity on genetically modified food was questioned, but she also questioned others’ objectivity.
articles.lead_paragraph: The politics of genetically modified food has created a rift in a policy-setting committee of the influential Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics that demonstrates the difficulty in finding anyone — anywhere — who doesn’t already have an opinion on the issue.

articles.headline: Gold, Long a Secure Investment, Loses Its Luster
articles.snippet: Gold has lost 17 percent of its value since 2011, a remarkable turnabout for an investment that many have regarded as one of the safest of all.
articles.abstract: Gold has lost 17 percent of its value since 2011, a remarkable turnabout for an investment that many have regarded as one of the safest of all.
articles.lead_paragraph: Below the streets of Lower Manhattan, in the vault of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the world’s largest trove of gold — half a million bars — has lost about $75 billion of its value. In Fort Knox, Ky., at the United States Bullion Depository, the damage totals $50 billion.

articles.headline: At 11th Hour, China’s Censors Bar ‘Django Unchained’
articles.snippet: The Oscar-winning movie was pulled on its opening day despite reports that the filmmakers had edited scenes to comply with the wishes of Chinese censors.
articles.abstract: The Oscar-winning movie was pulled on its opening day despite reports that the filmmakers had edited scenes to comply with the wishes of Chinese censors.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The American film “Django Unchained” was abruptly pulled from theaters in China on Thursday, its opening day, a surprising move that underscored the fragility of Hollywood’s evolving relationship with the Chinese movie industry.
articles.byline: By Gerry Mullany and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
articles.snippet: Pressed by shooting victims and relatives of Americans slain in gun violence, the Senate voted to consider new legislation that had faced the threat of a filibuster by Republicans.
articles.abstract: Pressed by shooting victims and relatives of Americans slain in gun violence, the Senate voted to consider new legislation that had faced the threat of a filibuster by Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pressed by shooting victims and relatives of Americans slain in gun violence, the Senate on Thursday voted to begin an emotionally and politically charged debate on gun safety proposals as advocates of new laws overcame a Republican filibuster threat.
